byline.original: By THOMAS J. HAMILTONSpecial to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: Week Ended April 25, 1949 A renewal of the selling of Canadian free dollars, interrupted for the once a fortnight ago when it firmed slightly, depressed the value of that unit to 89.62 cents last Friday. This was the lowest since October, 1945, and...
docs.lead_paragraph: Week Ended April 25, 1949 A renewal of the selling of Canadian free dollars, interrupted for the once a fortnight ago when it firmed slightly, depressed the value of that unit to 89.62 cents last Friday. This was the lowest since October, 1945, and canceled all of the advantage acquired when it was lifted to parity with the American dollar last July.

docs.snippet: Jeanne Behrend, who appeared in recital at Times Hall last night, placed Aaron Copland's sonata in the choicest spot on her program. This is one of Mr. Copland's finest compositions and one of the best produced by an American composer in recent...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jeanne Behrend, who appeared in recital at Times Hall last night, placed Aaron Copland's sonata in the choicest spot on her program. This is one of Mr. Copland's finest compositions and one of the best produced by an American composer in recent years.

headline.main: BEHREND, PIANIST, HEARD IN RECITAL; Artist Offers Copland Sonata as Feature of Program -- Plays Brazilian Works

docs.snippet: After having completed its organization work with record speed and harmony, the United Nations General Assembly decided yesterday to postpone the opening' of full-dress debate on the Palestine question until tomorrow. Organization procedure marked...
docs.lead_paragraph: After having completed its organization work with record speed and harmony, the United Nations General Assembly decided yesterday to postpone the opening' of full-dress debate on the Palestine question until tomorrow. Organization procedure marked the opening of the special session on Holy Land problems, held at Flushing Meadow, Queens.

headline.main: AGENDA UP TODAY; Russian Wins a Delay of Debate on Listing Arab Independence Move JEWS' BID TO TALK PUT OFF Harmony Rules as Aranha Is Named President -- Austin Leaves to See Marshall U. N. SPEEDS ACTION ON PALESTINE ISSUE

docs.snippet: Despite renewed Arab appeals, the United Nations General Assembly refused yesterday to place on its agenda a proposal to discuss termination of the British mandate and the independence of Palestine.
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite renewed Arab appeals, the United Nations General Assembly refused yesterday to place on its agenda a proposal to discuss termination of the British mandate and the independence of Palestine.

headline.main: ARABS LOSE AGAIN; ASSEMBLY REJECTS MOVE ON PALESTINE; Nations Vote 15 to 24, With 10 Abstentions -- U.S. Leads Opposition to Proposal RUSSIANS SUPPORT IT Discussion of Independence of Area Held Likely Anyhow During the Debates Arabs Lose Move in U.N. Assembly

byline.original: Special to THE NEW YORK TIMES

docs.snippet: RIO DE JANEIRO -- Fall perhaps the pleasantest season of the year, is now here in its fullness as spring advances in the United States, and it is upon the fact that it is winter in these parts when the summer heat is at its worst in the States that...
docs.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO -- Fall perhaps the pleasantest season of the year, is now here in its fullness as spring advances in the United States, and it is upon the fact that it is winter in these parts when the summer heat is at its worst in the States that South America is basing its hopes for the largest tourist season since the war.

headline.main: GAY DAYS IN SOUTH AMERICA; Plane Service Improved, Fares Cut -- Shipping Space Still Tight

docs.snippet: ALTHOUGH the ocean-travel picture has improved since last summer, with a score of liners entering or resuming service in pre-war finery, the travel-hungry American faces the prospect of remaining landlocked for at least another year.
docs.lead_paragraph: ALTHOUGH the ocean-travel picture has improved since last summer, with a score of liners entering or resuming service in pre-war finery, the travel-hungry American faces the prospect of remaining landlocked for at least another year.

headline.main: LINERS ARE NOW BOOKED TO CAPACITY; Acute Shortage of Space Expected to Last Until Next Year -- Cruises Planned
